DataElement.preferredDefinition: Code for the location of the largest polyp in the colon.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Biggest (in size) colon polyp in a group under consideration.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Greatest in size of those under consideration.:The part of the large intestine between the cecum and the rectum; it extracts moisture from food residues before they are excreted.

Concepts.definition: Greatest in size of those under consideration.

The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

Property.preferredDefinition: A general descriptive term used with reference to any mass of tissue that bulges or projects outward or upward from the normal surface level, thereby being macroscopically visible as a hemispheroidal, spheroidal, or irregular moundlike structure growing from a relatively broad base or a slender stalk. Classically applied to a growth on the mucous membrane of the nose, the term is now applied to such protrusions from any mucous membrane. (From Stedman, 25th ed; Dorland, 27th ed)

Concepts.definition: A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: CTMS:caBIG Clinical Trials Management Systems Workspace

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Code for the location of the largest polyp in the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Concepts.definition: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the colon that connects to the descending colon above and the rectum below.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the colon that connects to the descending colon above and the rectum below.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fourth portion of the large intestine (colon) that communicates with the transverse colon in the left-upper quadrant of the abdomen and the rectum below.

Concepts.definition: The fourth portion of the large intestine (colon) that communicates with the transverse colon in the left-upper quadrant of the abdomen and the rectum below.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bend at the junction of the transverse and descending colon.

Concepts.definition: The bend at the junction of the transverse and descending colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The third division of the colon (large intestine). It communicates with the ascending colon in the upper right-hand quadrant of the abdomen and the descending colon in the upper left-hand quadrant.

Concepts.definition: The third division of the colon (large intestine). It communicates with the ascending colon in the upper right-hand quadrant of the abdomen and the descending colon in the upper left-hand quadrant.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bend of the colon at the juncture of its ascending and transverse portions.

Concepts.definition: The bend of the colon at the juncture of its ascending and transverse portions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The first part of the colon (large intestine) that starts in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen and ends at the transverse colon in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen.

Concepts.definition: The first part of the colon (large intestine) that starts in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen and ends at the transverse colon in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A blind pouch-like commencement of the colon in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the end of the small intestine and the start of the large intestin

Concepts.definition: A blind pouch-like commencement of the colon in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the end of the small intestine and the start of the large intestine.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract. Concepts.definition: Greatest in size of those under consideration.

The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations.
A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
